bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, January 9, 1954

div1.p: Hench discusses his promotion regarding the Finlay Medal and how much the Finlay Medals will mean to the Reed, Lazear, Truby, and Carroll families.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, January 9, 1954
div1.opener:
January 9, 1954
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
It is curious that you and I should be thinking of each other and writing
at the same time. Thank you very much indeed for your letter of January 3.
I am delighted that Lambert was able to visit Camp Lazear. I am anxious
to know of his reactions and yours to his visit.

How generous you are, Pedro, to sponsor my promotion to the rank of Comenda-
dor of the Finlay Medal. I received the formal diploma yesterday. In-
cidentally, does this entitle me to an even more impressive medal, such
as one of those that hang around the neck? If so, I would like to have
it and you can perhaps help me get one when I come to Havana in a couple
of weeks. You know me - as pleased as a child with a medal. However per-
haps I am still only entitled to the lapel medal. But I can assure you I
am greatly pleased and honored.

I know very well, good friend, that you are mostly responsible, but please
tell me if there is someone else that I should also write to so that I can
express my thanks adequately.

I am delighted that you have included Doctor Carroll. That will complete
the group and I agree with you that his family should get it even if his
son failed to respond to your original letter. His son, George S. H. Carroll,
died recently. I expect to be in Washington on February 18 and have
made a date to visit Mrs. Carroll. I would be delighted indeed to take
the decoration to her but perhaps it would be much better if you sent the
decoration to the Cuban Embassy and had them present it to the widow. She
and the family would like that much better. I don't believe Mr. and Mrs.
George S. H. Carroll (son of Doctor James Carroll) had any children but
George has a couple of sisters living. Mrs. George S. H. Carroll's ad-
dress is: 2814 Rhode Island Avenue N.E., Washington, D. C.

I am sure that those who received the Finlay Medal last year, the Reeds,
Lazears, Truby, etc., will be delighted indeed to receive them when you
can arrange it.
It will be grand to see you in a couple of weeks.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
